resources.string: On August 21st, 2017, a total solar eclipse will occur across North America. This app makes it easy to capture images of the eclipse. Your images can also become part of an exciting citizen science project.

Everyone! This app does all the hard work of controlling your smartphone camera to capture images of the eclipse at just the right times. You can use it just with your phone or with an external lens and tripod to get even sharper images of this once-in-a-lifetime event.

The app is very easy to use. You just have to point your phone in the right direction during the eclipse and the app takes the pictures for you. If you have an external lens and tripod, the app will help you set everything up to get the best shots possible.
How do I use the app?

Even a short glance at the sun can cause permanent eye damage. That’s also true during the first and last phases of an eclipse when the sun’s disk is partially covered. So while the dimmer light of a partial eclipse may tempt you, the only time you can safely view the sun is the short period called totality, when the sun is completely covered by the moon.

About Megamovie Mobile

The Megamovie Mobile app allows you to capture images of the solar eclipse on August 21, 2017. It also lets you share your photos with scientists for a citizen science project led by UC Berkeley’s Space Sciences Laboratory and Google. Click here to learn more. 

The app can capture valuable scientific information without additional equipment. But you can obtain even better results with an external lens and tripod. If you already have this equipment or want to learn more, use our built-in Eclipse Orientation to customize the app. 

If you are using an external lens and tripod, the app has a Calibration mode that will help you focus the lens and point the camera in the right direction. You can practice by capturing images of the moon. 

One outcome of the Megamovie Project will be a movie of the eclipse as it moves across the US. The movie will incorporate high-quality images captured by trained volunteers with DSLR cameras. Once it is available, you can download and view it in the Eclipse Megamovie section.

The Megamovie Mobile app is designed to help you use your camera phone to take the best possible images of the solar eclipse. It tells you when and where to see the eclipse, how to aim your camera when the eclipse is about to start, and automatically controls your camera’s settings and shutter to take a series of photos during the event. All you’ll have to do is be ready and follow a few simple instructions when the time comes.\n\nThe app also gives you a way to practice before the eclipse so you’ll feel comfortable when the big day arrives—by taking pictures of the moon. Go to Moon test to try it out.

Holding a camera by hand can cause tiny vibrations that blur photos. This can be especially troublesome with astronomical images. Mounting your phone on a tripod is an easy way to improve your photos. There are many kinds of tripods available for cell phones, including inexpensive ones made by Joby, Square Jellyfish, and Charger City. 

Also, while your phone may have a great camera, images of the sun are likely to be small unless you use an external lens like those made by Olloclip, Moment, Mozeat, and instaLens. Lenses like these are easy to attach to your phone and can help you take great photos of many things in addition to the eclipse. 

Go to Calibrate your camera to set up your phone with a tripod and lens.

If you want to use a separate camera to photograph the eclipse, you can still use the eclipse map and countdown functions in the Megamovie Mobile app. You can view those features here. This is when the edge of the moon first begins to cover the sun. Even though the sun will start to get dimmer at this point, it’s still not safe to look directly at the eclipse.\n

In a total solar eclipse, this is when totality begins and the sun’s disk is completely covered by the moon. You can now see the corona, the sun’s hot, hazy outer atmosphere. Be sure to look away before totality ends.\n
Third contact is the moment when totality ends and the sun begins to emerge from the moon’s shadow.\n
This is the end of the eclipse, when the moon’s shadow no longer covers any part of the sun.\n

Signing in with your Google Account allows Megamovie Mobile to upload the eclipse images automatically to a server, to be added to the public-domain Megamovie archive. This repository, the first of its kind, will enable scientists and the public to make discoveries about the Moon and about the Sun.
